Title: Grieving the Dream
Overall Purpose: To fully grieve the venture, role, or vision that is ending so that love for what it was can coexist with clarity for what comes next.
Why This Matters: Un-grieved dreams keep us entangled with the past. Deliberate grief protects coherence, restores energy, and prevents old longings from distorting new work.
When To Use This Protocol: When a startup path, identity, or cherished plan is ending (or needs to), and you want a clean, human, future-facing way to let it go.

Overall Outcomes.Poor: Grief is bypassed or performed. Energy stays stuck; the past quietly steers the future.
Overall Outcomes.Expected: Grief is felt and named without drama. You can honor what was and release it.
Overall Outcomes.Excellent: Grief becomes a source of insight and continuity. Gifts are carried forward, residue is cleared.
Overall Outcomes.Transcendent: The goodbye enlarges you. Love for the dream becomes fuel that stabilizes a wiser next chapter.

Themes.Name: Naming What’s Dying
Themes.Purpose of This Theme: To say plainly which part of the dream is ending—and which parts are not.
Themes.Why This Matters: Ambiguity prolongs pain. Precision allows compassion and release.

Poor.Example moves: Sentence pair: ‘What is ending is… What is not ending is…’

Excellent.Present pattern: Links the ending to timing, criteria, and care.

Transcendent.Present pattern: Names the ending as a field transition.
Transcendent.Example moves: Ritual line: ‘Thank you. You may rest.’

Guiding Questions: What remains alive beyond this ending?
What date or boundary marks the end?

Themes.Name: Making Space to Feel
Themes.Purpose of This Theme: To allow grief to move through the body, not just the mind.
Themes.Why This Matters: Unfelt grief leaks into tone, decisions, and relationships.

Expected.Present pattern: Creates small, real containers to feel.

Excellent.Present pattern: Somatic practices help grief move cleanly.

Transcendent.Present pattern: Feeling becomes an act of stewardship.
Transcendent.30-90 day system effect: Culture permits human truth without collapse.
Transcendent.Example moves: Open a meeting with ‘I’m grieving this…’.

Guiding Questions: Where does grief sit in my body?
What small container will I actually use today?
What would feeling—without fixing—look like now?

Themes.Name: Separating Identity from the Dream
Themes.Purpose of This Theme: To decouple self-worth from the venture’s fate.
Themes.Why This Matters: When identity fuses with a dream, endings feel annihilating.

Poor.Example moves: Write 3 truths about you that persist beyond this.

Expected.Present pattern: Identity is named as larger than the venture.
Expected.Example moves: List roles you still carry independent of this dream.

Excellent.Present pattern: You consciously design post-dream identity anchors.
Excellent.Signals: Simpler story about who you are.
Excellent.Example moves: Define 2 anchors: practice, relationship, or place.
Excellent.Future effect: A steadier self leads the next work.

Transcendent.Present pattern: Self expands through grieving; humility deepens.
Transcendent.Example moves: Name the gift the dream gave your character.

Guiding Questions: What part of me fused with this dream?
What of me was never this dream?
What anchors hold me beyond it?

Themes.Name: Harvesting the Gifts
Themes.Purpose of This Theme: To preserve lessons, assets, and relationships worth carrying forward.
Themes.Why This Matters: If we don’t name what lives, we lose compounding value.

Poor.Example moves: List 5 gifts: skill, asset, relationship, insight, ritual.

Excellent.Edge condition: Don’t force weak gifts to live.
Excellent.Example moves: Put gifts on the roadmap with dates.

Guiding Questions: Which gifts are alive and reusable?
Where will the top two be used in 60 days?
Who needs to receive each gift?

Themes.Name: Repairing Invisible Bonds
Themes.Purpose of This Theme: To clear subtle resentments or unspoken apologies tied to the dream.
Themes.Why This Matters: Invisible bonds keep attention tethered to the past.

Poor.Present pattern: Avoids repair or makes vague gestures.

Expected.Present pattern: Addresses one concrete repair or amends.

Excellent.Present pattern: Completes small repairs across key relationships.
Excellent.Example moves: Prioritize top 2 residues and clear them.

Transcendent.Present pattern: Relational fabric becomes stronger than before.
Transcendent.Example moves: Offer a tailored intro or thanks.

Guiding Questions: Who do I owe an acknowledgment or amends to?
What exactly needs to be said?
What channel and tone will keep it clean?

Themes.Name: Ritual of Goodbye and Recommitment
Themes.Purpose of This Theme: To close with a simple ritual that blesses what was and turns toward what’s next.
Themes.Why This Matters: Ritual anchors memory and releases attachment.

Expected.Example moves: Say the goodbye line; one breath; place an object.

Excellent.Present pattern: Names one living thread and a first next step.

Transcendent.Present pattern: Ritual becomes a cultural practice of dignified endings.
Transcendent.Example moves: Share a simple ‘how we end’ note.

Guiding Questions: What words bless this dream as it ends?
What single living thread do we carry?
What smallest next step affirms the new chapter?

Completion Prompts: Write the one-line obituary for the dream—and the one-line blessing.
List two gifts you will reuse within the next 60 days and name their owners.
Name one repair to complete and one ritual act to close.

Primary Scenarios: A founder or team faces the end of a cherished venture path and needs a dignified, future-facing closure.
